ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by CT scan showing a 4-5 cm mass in the left CPA and pathology report indicating schwannoma.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA) Tumor
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Large mass lesion identified on CT, causing brainstem compression signs (contralateral ABR abnormalities, limb numbness).

ordered_list.rationale_short: To evaluate speech recognition and check for retrocochlear signs.
To assess the integrity of the reflex arc; absence with normal hearing suggests retrocochlear pathology.
To evaluate neural synchrony and brainstem function given the asymmetric symptoms.
To visualize the cerebellopontine angle and confirm the presence of a mass.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presented with normal pure tone thresholds bilaterally but significant retrocochlear signs on the left, including reduced speech recognition (80%) and absent acoustic reflexes. ABR results were grossly abnormal on the left and showed signs of brainstem compression on the right (absent/diminished Wave V). A CT scan confirmed a large (4-5 cm) left acoustic schwannoma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Essentially normal pure tone thresholds bilaterally (0-20 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear speech recognition dropped to 80%; Right ear 92%. No rollover observed.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Contralateral reflexes absent with left ear stimulation; normal with right ear stimulation.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Left ear: Wave I clear (1.44 ms), subsequent waves abnormal/indistinguishable. Right ear: Wave V absent or markedly diminished, suggesting brainstem compression.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Large mass lesion (4-5 cm) in the left CPA; pathology confirmed schwannoma.

counseling_actions: Explain that normal pure tone thresholds do not rule out auditory nerve tumors.
Discuss the correlation between neurologic symptoms (facial tingling, limb numbness) and the large mass compressing the brainstem.
Review ABR findings, explaining how the tumor affects the non-involved ear via brainstem compression.
Discuss the plasticity of younger brains in accommodating neural compromise, which can mask symptom severity.

escalation.rationale_short: Confirmed large acoustic schwannoma with signs of brainstem compression.

expected_outcome: Post-surgical hearing status: No hearing remained in the left ear.
Post-surgical hearing status: Right ear thresholds remained stable.
